list.item: Aunt Lizzie & Mrs. Proffitt make the living room comfortable (according to their ideas) -
More visiting around before my leaving Tues. April 6th

p.del: Dearest family: The skirt has just come & is perfectly lovely - am so overcome with it - it is so pretty - Jane and you are simply a dear to do this for me and I shall get even some time I hope. It will not be any trouble to put in the hem - & shall wait until I get to civilization that is Knoxville or Washington D.C. before shortening it - imagine the skirts are movable again as to length - varying in different places aren't they?

div1.p:
It is 1:30 & am gowned & in my "mud boats" preparatory to a flight of four miles up the river to Crockil Maples - for the night - am a gay butterfly this week doing society stuff only - Guess I'll get my
trunk packed between spasms - hope so because it's to be down to Calvin Ogle's store tomorrow - so there will be plenty of time for waiting for a chance team to take it to the Forge. Have decided to leave here Tuesday morning via Dan & the buggy & take afternoon train from S. to Knoxville - meeting Abby at the depot - Will have to close up my banking for thanks to Mabel I am a firm believer now in the check system.

Am writing so fast as I'm in a hurry to get started before the rain descends as it looks quite like doing - am sick of rain positively - but maybe it won't. Fear if I do not scratch this off now I won't get it in the mail tomorrow - and do want it to go out.

p.del: Well I was charmed as usual to get both your letters Monday & absorb all their contents from gardening - antoug - assessing - cleaning etc. Such a busy family as I belong to you make me think of Heinz - 57 varieties with the multiplicity & kinds of tasks you both indulge in.

div1.p:
Wish you could peep into the living room now & cast your eye around - You would behold Aunt Lizzie sitting by the fire picking over wool - Mrs Proffitt is ironing - board is stretched from the other end of the library table to a chair - her irons are heated at the fireplace - a bed couch adorns the side of the room between the windows - I knew Aunt Lizzie would get a bed in here when Evelyn left - she did it last fall & we had quite a time working it out without hurting her feelings - a broom also adorns one end of the fireplace - The two of them have been discussing the new styles at Calvin's store - Well I'm chatting idly & to no purpose - Monday right after breakfast Aunt Lizzie & I went up to Russell Ogle's nearly a mile from here - Mrs. O. has been sick you know - We took her some oranges & "light bread" - and found her much better. It was a lovely morning & on our way back we stopped at another house to visit a sick girl - she too was better & we resumed our journey homeward - Then as we went along the river road I beheld a young lady & elderly woman approaching - strangers - They smiled & stopped & I discovered they were the two
who had written Miss Evelyn about coming - Nell Wheeler & her mother from Indianapolis. Miss W. teaches English in a high school - and is very sweet & nice. They wanted to get a horse and buggy for the p.m. & asked so I said I'd find out if Harrison were going to use Dan. We had an early dinner & then I went right over to H's & found them all at dinner - he Lila & the four youngsters - I fooled around - visited with them took their pictures etc - then started on to the hotel after getting my mail - and enroute stopped at Maple's & told Emma to come & "knock about" with me all afternoon (They say "knock about" here for visiting) She said she'd get ready so then I finally got to the hotel & told the Wheelers they could have the horse & visited
with them - Then we started up to the cottage - First I stopped at the store to cash a check & get thread & found a number in there whom I know - Mrs. Huff - Betty - Mrs. Whaley & Mrs. McCarter (Tom's mother) who asked me to stay all night & am going there Saturday - but more of that ano anon. Well eventually I got the Wheelers' off & then Emma & I knocked around - going up Roaring Fork & calling at Josie's & the Parton's - got back & went over to the old schoolhouse on the hill & watched the sun set. Had supper of bread & milk & went to bed. Isn't this interesting? Yesterday I started right after breakfast to the hotel as I'd promised to go around with the Wheelers' - It was another
perfect day - and we walked up Roaring Fork - stopping at various places to take pictures & visit - met some of my youngsters & showed them the pictures I'd take the last of school which were pretty good - Eventually we got to Maud Clabo's & visited at her grandmothers. They expect to move into their new house this week - Maud was helping fix the plaster for the "chimley" -

We got back at noon - I cleaned up & ate - Mr. Cresswell then arrived - then Miss Wheeler - for we were going up Baskin's - we visited enroute & took pictures stopped at Lana Ogle's where I'd promised to stay all night so had my little bag in case the time was propitious. It was & we got Lana & her sister - & went on up to the old schoolhouse & to some falls - Then Miss Wheeler left me at Ogle's - I wen had a very nice time visiting with them - was in bed by eight - a whole room to myself with two double beds - & up by 4:10 - home by 6:30 - Such is life here! Washed & read then Miss W. arrived & we went up to Tom Camel' - had a nice visit with them & wonderful view of the mts. Since then have gotten my dinner - mail - changed dress & am ready for my next night out - Have written very hastily - but thought this was better than nothing - must hurry on - Am very well - fat & red - have had two little colds & hoarse once last fall - You remember how I got that way before - no cold just lost my voice - So "don't worry" - no more smallpox - Ephraim - the present victim went fishing the other day - Loads of love to all as ever - Ruth -
